Um, so the linear wave is the main
driving force of this whole shader. In
its simplest form, it's really just a
repeating linear gradient from zero to
one, which we obtained through our
mesh's UVs. And it is scrolling along
the surface of our mesh. Uh, yeah,
scrolling on the surface of our mesh.
Once this part is achieved, we simply
mask out some of those gradients to
break the pattern a little bit. And
that's it. Everything else is built on
top of this. So I know to some people in
uh in here there this might be a very
simple thing to do. Um but because it is
so foundational to the rest of the
system, we'll have a look at how to
build this thing. So the first step uh
on the left what you see here is the
mesh's UVs as we would see them if we
were to output the uh UVs in the
emissive color of the shader. So UVs are
2D vectors. Uh so when used as a color
they occupy the red and uh green channel
respectively U and V. Um, and if we
isolate just a U component, uh, we end
up with this perfect black and white
linear gradient from 0 to one, which
spans the width of our mesh.
Now, if we multiply this U component by
a value greater than one, much like when
we're tiling textures, we will be tiling
our gradient pattern. However, the
numerical values being output by the
multiply node here will no longer be
from zero to one. For example, if we
multiply it by five, they will be from
zero to five. But we do want to make
sure that our data remains between zero
and one because we want to drive a
system with these values from 0 to one.
So, uh this is where the frack node uh
becomes handy. Frack will return only
the fractional portion of your scalar of
the scaler that you feed it. So 2.3
would return 0.3, 4.75 would return 75,
etc.
Once we have this pattern, we can now
add the notion of time in the shader by
simply adding a time node in between our
multiply and frack nodes. And this is
what gets our pattern to crawl at a
fixed speed uh over the surface of our
mesh.
In the next step, we will want to skew
our pattern uh along the length of the
mesh. So to do this, we will be adding
the V component of the UVs on top of the
U component that we already uh
extracted. So the V component is also a
gradient from 0 to one. But unlike the U
component which stretches along the
width of our mesh, the V component
stretches along the length of our mesh.
And so multiplying this V component by a
either a negative or positive value
before adding it on top of the U
component as we see in the graph uh will
effectively skew our pattern on one side
or the other respectively.
And the final step that we'll do today
as far as the linear wave is concerned
is going to use a modulo and saturate
operators to mask out some of our waves.
uh the combination of modulo saturation
and frack that we see here might be
somewhat more exotic to some people. So
uh we'll have a very quick look at what
it does just to make sure everyone is

the effect that we see in the picture
here and I also promise that this will
be the highest level of mats that we
will be doing today. Um so uh before we

the second uh operator of the um the uh

three. We will be using that in a

here. Uh the way to visualize this is
just like a function. The horizontal
x-axis is the value that we send to our

the regular linear progression of the
unmodified value of x or in this case
the r channel in the top right image. Uh
meaning that if you follow this graph a

value and we feed it into a modulo by3
just like in our node uh network two
slides ago uh this is what we would get.
Uh modulo by3 means that as the value of
x increases we will continue to be
looping through the values between zero
and the upper end three in this case. So
as we can see here in the graph, one
would return one, two would return two.
But as we hit uh an x value of three,
the modulo function would loop back to
zero such that three would return zero,
4.5 would return 1.5. Uh 5.7 would
return 2.7. And then once we reach six,
the value returns to zero uh once again
and so on forever creating a pattern
that loops from 0 to three to infinity.
Then we want to add to add the saturate
operator which simply clamps our values
between zero and one flattening our
curve when they used to return between
one and three. So this is what we see in
green here. Uh so we now have a pattern
that goes from zero to one, stays at the
value of one for a while and then loops
back to zero and start over again to
infinity.
And uh lastly, it was getting a bit
crowded in the graph, so I cleaned it up
a bit. But here we are connecting
everything that we just did to our frack
operator, which causes the flat line
that was previously at 1.0 to go down to
zero. Since the frack operator keeps
only the fractional part and the
fractional part of 1.0 is zero. So
instead of having a flat line at one, we
now have a flat line at zero. So now our
final pattern goes from uh 0 to one
linearly then immediately sets to zero
uh resets to zero and stays there for a
while and then once again goes from zero
to one linearly and so on. And so, uh,
putting all of this together, uh, is how
we go from the pattern on the left that
we started with to the pattern on the
right, which gives us space spaced out
linear waves.
